children.subject: Thank you, Kartik!
Thanks Professor Shewchuck. I hope you're enjoying a good cup of tea right now.
My pleasure.
Thank you for explaining!
The wait list just got expanded to 800~

Thank you Professor Shewchuck, 

If the system says the class wait list is also full during enrollment, what should we do?
I’m pretty sure waitlist position is just determined by when you sign up.

Thanks, but I meant after students are given a waitlist position number... Does registration system put students in the enrolled list base on their position number and major(EECS undergard first and non-EECS undergrad second)

The enrollment system im pretty sure will attempt to enroll based off of waitlist number. By attempt I mean it will try to enroll the student - if the student does not meet the reserve requirements (just based off of major - not GPA) - then the attempt has failed, and the enrollment system moves to the next person on the waitlist. i.e. if will start at 1, if it cannot enroll waitlist student 1, it will move to 2 and so on.

To my understanding this is how it works but someone can feel free to correct / add on
Thank you Alex. I think you meant because 189 doesn't have reserved seats for EECS students, so eecs undergrad has no priority over non-eecs undergrad.
from https://classes.berkeley.edu/content/2019-spring-compsci-189-001-lec-001 it seems like all seats are reserved for eecs/cs until after phase 2, right?

I believe 189 is strictly reserved for undergrad, and 289 is reserved for grad students, they each have their own seating pools - however I don't know if / when the class is expanded to 744 students if all open seats will be allocated to 189 or split between 189/289
Looks like 189 doesn't have any reserved seats for eecs/cs major.
Does the registration system prioritize undergrad students base on their position number and major(EECS first), GPA,...?
Expand to 690 now!
I saw the class was expanded to 476 students, is there any chance of it expanding more? Or is that the limit?
Enrolled! Thank you, Professor Shewchuk.

I am an EECS undergrad, waitlist position at 395. If I stay in the class and do all the work by Feb.13(last day to add/drop), how likely I will be in? Anyone who has similar experience can give me some advice? (Spring/19 will be my last semester in Berkeley, it will be sad if I miss this class.)

Does it look like there will ever be a way for non-EECS grad students to take 289? I've tried for several semesters in a row now, and it seems that there is never enough room. Currently quite high (high=bad) on the grad wait list, so I don't think it's likely I will get in. Thanks!
Will the registration for non-EECS grad student ever be opened??

history.content:
Enrollment in CS 189/289A (Machine Learning) is prioritized as follows.

  1. EECS graduate students have highest priority.
  2. Undergraduates are second.  (Priority among undergrads will be as customarily determined by the registration system.)
  3. Non-EECS graduate students are third.
  4. Concurrent enrollment students are last.

To accommodate the first two groups, we might not be able to enroll non-EECS graduate students until the semester has already started, depending on demand.  Sorry.  Stay on the waitlist and have hope.  (If any concurrent enrollment students are enrolled, it probably won't happen until the second or third week of classes.)

IMPORTANT:  189 is for undergraduates only; 289A is for grad students only.  If you're an undergrad, you won't be permitted to enroll in 289A.  (Sorry, we won't have enough TA support to offer projects for undergrads.)  If you're a grad student who tries to enroll in 189, you'll be manually kicked out of the class once an administrator catches you, so enroll in 289A.  (If you care about the reason why, ask me in person.)

Students are already asking me whether the class will expand.  Here's how that works.

  1. First, we need to have enough people on the waitlist to justify...
  2. asking the department for extra $. If the department says yes, then...
  3. we see if we can hire enough TAs to teach the extra sections. If so, then...
  4. we can let more students into the course.

But the department doesn't offer us extra $ until we demonstrate substantial excess demand (factoring in that we expect about 100 students to drop), so please get on the waitlist soon if you want to take the class.

Thank you,

Jonathan Shewchuk

UPDATE:  The class will probably (not guaranteed yet) expand to enroll 744 students.  The bad news is that there are currently 1,014 students enrolled or waitlisted for 189+289A, so things aren't looking good for non-EECS grad students.
history.subject: Info on enrolling in CS 189/289A

history.content:
Enrollment in CS 189/289A (Machine Learning) is prioritized as follows.

  1. EECS graduate students have highest priority.
  2. Undergraduates are second.  (Priority among undergrads will be as customarily determined by the registration system.)
  3. Non-EECS graduate students are third.
  4. Concurrent enrollment students are last.

To accommodate the first two groups, we might not be able to enroll non-EECS graduate students until the semester has already started, depending on demand.  Sorry.  Stay on the waitlist and have hope.  (If any concurrent enrollment students are enrolled, it probably won't happen until the second or third week of classes.)

IMPORTANT:  189 is for undergraduates only; 289A is for grad students only.  If you're an undergrad, you won't be permitted to enroll in 289A.  (Sorry, we won't have enough TA support to offer projects for undergrads.)  If you're a grad student who tries to enroll in 189, you'll be manually kicked out of the class once an administrator catches you, so enroll in 289A.  (If you care about the reason why, ask me in person.)

Students are already asking me whether the class will expand.  Here's how that works.

  1. First, we need to have enough people on the waitlist to justify...
  2. asking the department for extra $. If the department says yes, then...
  3. we see if we can hire enough TAs to teach the extra sections. If so, then...
  4. we can let more students into the course.

But the department doesn't offer us extra $ until we demonstrate substantial excess demand (factoring in that we expect about 100 students to drop), so please get on the waitlist soon if you want to take the class.

Thank you,

Jonathan Shewchuk

P.S.  The fact that they scheduled the class in Wheeler Auditorium might be a hint that the department is probably willing to pay if the demand materializes.
